=== Game Rules ===
Game rules in natural language:
Here’s a plain‐language breakdown of the game’s design and some advice for how to tackle it:

1. Game Genre and Overall Feel  
 • It’s a top‐down, maze‑ or puzzle-like arcade adventure.  
 • You navigate a grid‑based level full of walls, floors, key items, a locked door (“goal”), and roaming enemies.  
 • The gameplay mixes exploration, simple combat (using a temporary “sword” attack), and puzzle elements (finding and using a key).

2. Core Mechanics  
 • Movement is done on a tiled layout (walls, floors, etc.).  
 • The player controls an “avatar” that can shoot a short‑lived sword attack.  
 • The level includes various non-player characters: fast, normal, and slow “monster” enemies that move randomly.  
 • Collecting a key is crucial; note that collecting it changes a “nokey” sprite into one “withkey” (this seems to represent the transformation of your character or an ally that now carries the key).  
 • Some interactions are “passive” as well – for example, if a sprite without a key (nokey) bumps into a door (goal), it is blocked (“stepBack”). Only a sprite holding the key (withkey) can interact with the door to “open” it (the door is then killed and points are awarded).

3. Objective and Win/Loss Conditions  
 • Your overall objective is to complete the level by “opening” the door (goal).  
 • To do that, you must (directly or indirectly) obtain the key so that you can interact properly with the door.  
 • You win when the goal sprite (door) is cleared from the level.  
 • You lose if your avatar is removed from play (likely by taking enemy damage or otherwise being “killed” by an enemy).

4. Suggested Overall Strategy  
 • First, explore the maze carefully to locate the key. The transformation rule (nokey + key → withkey) suggests that acquiring the key is essential before you can use the door.  
 • While searching, be mindful of enemy movement. The fast, normal, and slow monsters patrol the level randomly.  
 • Use your sword attack wisely. With a limited duration (a “flicker” effect) and a cap on how many attacks can be active, time your shots to take out enemies that block your path or threaten your progress.  
 • Avoid direct collisions with enemies using your avatar, since that interaction carries a score penalty and risks your survival.  
 • Once you – or your controlled sprite – has the key, head for the door. Note that only an entity carrying the key (the “withkey” sprite) is allowed to “open” the door; the door will not respond to a sprite that hasn’t acquired the key.  
 • Keep an eye on your surroundings and use cover (walls and floor patterns) to dodge monsters while advancing. Tactical retreats and waiting out enemy “cooldowns” (monsters’ movement impulses) can be very effective.

By combining careful maze exploration, timely offense (sword attacks), and avoiding enemy collisions, you can safely secure the key and reach the door to win the level while keeping your score in the positive.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT
4: ACTION_DOWN
5: ACTION_UP

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.
